wikipedia_page.main: David Kwame Barnett (born 16 April 1967) is an English former football player and coach who played as a defender in the Football League for Colchester United, Walsall, Barnet, Birmingham City, Port Vale and Lincoln City. He also represented Dunfermline Athletic in the Scottish Premier League and Edmonton Brick Men in the Canadian Soccer League. He made more than 200 appearances for nearly 20 clubs during his career. He later coached non-League Romulus.

response: During a Rangers/Padres broadcast on Monday, June 18, 2012, from Petco Park in San Diego, Barnett suddenly began making nonsensical statements during the bottom of the eighth inning. Rangers pitching coach Mike Maddux was concluding a visit to the mound with pitcher Mike Adams when Barnett, without warning, said, "Go-ahead run is at fifth [pause] on what Adams is insisting on calling it a botched robbery. What actually happened was [pause] his henchmen took a piece literally out of . . . .".  Retrieved on September 15, 2012. At that point, Barnett's voice trailed off. It sounded as though he was struggling to say the words "my" and then "his," but could not do so.Id. There was initial speculation that the broadcast production crew had turned off his microphone, but they actually had not done so.Barry Horn, Baseball: Diagnosis for Dave Barnett is "complicated migraine", Dallas Morning News (June 27, 2012).  Retrieved on September 15, 2012. For about twenty seconds, Barnett was silent, with viewers hearing only ambient noise from the ballpark.Joey Matschulat, The Strangest Moment of Dave Barnett's Broadcasting Career, Baseball Time in Arlington (June 19, 2012; audio of the telecast is included).  Retrieved on September 16, 2012. Then, just as suddenly as the oddity appeared, it was over. Barnett began speaking again as if nothing had happened,Id. and he finished the game without further incident.Barry Horn, "Baseball: Diagnosis for Dave Barnett is 'complicated migraine'", supra.

Barnett never returned to the Rangers' broadcast booth after the June 18, 2012 incident. On July 2, 2012, Barnett said in a statement that he was taking an indefinite medical leave of absence that he expected would last for the remainder of the 2012 season.Timothy Burke, Rangers Broadcaster Dave Barnett Will Miss Rest of Season Due to Unspecified Medical Concerns, Deadspin (July 2, 2012).  Retrieved on September 15, 2012.Scott Bell, Texas Rangers broadcaster Dave Barnett to take leave of absence expected to last for remainder of season , Dallas Morning News (July 2, 2012).  Retrieved on September 15, 2012. He said in a telephone interview at the time that medical specialists were in disagreement as to what had caused his problem.Id. Steve Busby continued as Barnett's replacement as the television play-by-play announcer.Id. On November 1, 2012, the Rangers issued a statement to the effect that they would not be renewing Barnett's contract, which had expired at the end of the 2012 season.SportsDaysDFW, Broadcaster Dave Barnett wishes things ended differently with Rangers, Dallas Morning News (November 2, 2012).  Retrieved on November 9, 2012.

On September 4, 2012, Barnett announced that he would do the television play-by-play for two football games of the University of North Texas, the school from which Barnett graduated in 1979 (when it was called North Texas State University).Barry Horn, Broadcaster Dave Barnett returns to call North Texas-Texas Southern game, Dallas Morning News (September 4, 2012.  Retrieved on September 15, 2012.Associated Press, Dave Barnett to return to booth, from ESPN.com (September 5, 2012).  Retrieved on September 15, 2012. He broadcast the first game on September 8, 2012, with no problems.Barry Horn, Dave Barnett's return to the television booth for UNT football goes off without a glitch , from SportsDay DFW (September 14, 2012).  Retrieved on September 15, 2012. He said at the time that, despite a battery of tests, doctors had not been able to determine what had caused his sudden incoherence in June.Id. On November 10, 2012, Barnett broadcast his second UNT football game that season, again without incident. In May 2013, he did the play-by-play for Fox Sports Southwest's television broadcast of a college baseball game between Oklahoma State and West Virginia.Barry Horn, Ex-Rangers broadcaster Dave Barnett: Play-by-play return would be "ideal", Dallas Morning News (May 24, 2013).  Retrieved on June 8, 2013. In 2014, he was hired to be the play-by-play voice of Big 12 Conference baseball on Fox Sports 1. Beginning in 2015, he replaced fellow UNT alumnus George Dunham as the radio voice of Mean Green football and men's basketball.

He is married with two children and lives in Lantana, Texas.Mark Miller, Rangers TV broadcaster Dave Barnett enjoying life in Lantana , Allen Publishing (February 28, 2012).  Retrieved on March 23, 2013.
David or Dave Barnett may refer to:
*Dave Barnett (born 1958), American basketball, football and baseball sportscaster

At the end of the season, Lee Mills was signed by Premier League Bradford City, becoming Bradford's first million pound player. Twelve year club veteran Andy Porter signed for Wigan Athletic, as did Griffiths. Another major departure was nine-year club veteran defender Dean Glover, who joined non-league Kidderminster Harriers. Another older player, Andy Hill, retired outright. Other departures were Dave Barnett to Lincoln City, Dean Stokes to Third Division Rochdale, and Dutch keeper Arjan van Heusden also headed into the basement division with Cambridge United. Fellow Dutchman Jermaine Holwyn returned to the Netherlands to play for HFC Haarlem.
| March 1998 || DF ||  || Dave Barnett ||  Dunfermline Athletic || May 1998 ||

The pre-season saw John Rudge splash out £300,000 on Bristol Rovers forward Peter Beadle and £100,000 on Scunthorpe United defender Michael Walsh. He also signed Dave Barnett (Dunfermline Athletic); Brian McGlinchey and Paul Beesley (Manchester City); and John McQuade (Hamilton Academical) on free transfers. Stéphane Pounewatchy also became the first French player to play for the club when he was signed on a monthly contract from Dundee. Scott Mean was loaned to the club by West Ham United, though he went on to sustain a knee injury during his spell that would damage his career. Also Andy Clarke was signed on loan from Wimbledon.

At the end of the season there was a complete clear-out, with ten players leaving: ten-year club veteran Neil Aspin (Darlington); Dave Barnett (Lincoln City); Brian McGlinchey (Gillingham); John McQuade (Raith Rovers); Chris Allen (Stockport County); Rogier Koordes (TOP Oss); Jan Jansson (IFK Norrköping);  Paul Mahorn (Stevenage Borough); Stéphane Pounewatchy (Colchester United); and Paul Beesley (Blackpool).
